channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Netanyahu Defends His Plans for Gaza, Amid Outrage in Israel
item.description: After thousands of Israeli workers walked off the job on Monday, angry over the deaths of hostages in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said at a news conference that the war would only end when Israel had eliminated Hamas.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: Hamas Documents Reveal Tunnel Battle Strategy
item.description: Hamas leaders spent years developing an underground warfare plan. Records from the battlefield show the group’s preparations, including blast doors to protect against Israeli bombs and soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier walking out of a tunnel in the Gaza Strip during an escorted tour by the military for international journalists in December.

item.title: In a Kyiv Classroom, Cries for Help From Children Scarred by War
item.description: “They are like a bleeding wound, and no one sees it,” a schoolteacher said of her pupils, many of whom have fled frontline areas or lost family members in the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Listening to a lesson by the teacher Iryna Kovaliova at a school in Kyiv, Ukraine, in March.

item.title: Russia Hits Ukraine With Wave of Strikes as School Year Opens
item.description: The attack, the third large-scale bombardment in a week, coincided with intense fighting in eastern Ukraine and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters at the scene of a blaze in Kyiv on Monday, caused by debris from a downed Russian missile that hit a youth sports academy.

item.title: France Confronts Horror of Rape and Drugging Case as 51 Men Go on Trial
item.description: A man is accused of drugging his wife and then inviting dozens of men to rape her over almost a decade. The questions raised by the case have unsettled the country.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Ashley Tinker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The trial in Avignon involves a case of sexual abuse that has shocked and disturbed France.

item.title: Putin Arrives in Mongolia in Defiance of I.C.C. Arrest Warrant
item.description: The Russian president is making a state visit to a country that is heavily dependent on Moscow for oil.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and David Pierson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Natalia Gubernatorova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In this photograph distributed by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin is accompanied by Battsetseg Batmunkh, Mongolia’s foreign minister, upon Mr. Putin’s arrival at the airport in Ulaanbaatar.

item.title: Order to Block Elon Musk’s X in Brazil Is Upheld
item.description: Mr. Musk has criticized the blackout of the social network in Brazil as a campaign by a single, crusading justice. On Monday, four other justices affirmed the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Ueslei Marcelino/Reuters
item.media:description: Judge Alexandre de Moraes at the Brazilian Supreme Court. On Friday, he issued an order to block Elon Musk’s social network X.

item.title: Takeaways From East Germany’s State Elections
item.description: The far-right Alternative for Germany, or AfD, had a very successful night in two states, despite its state chapters’ classification as “extremist” by German domestic intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Thilo Schmuelgen/Reuters
item.media:description: Björn Höcke, a member of the AfD, left, Thuringia State Premier Bodo Ramelow, center, and the Christian Democratic Union candidate Mario Voigt, right, at the state parliament building in Erfurt, Germany, on Sunday.

item.title: Pope Francis Begins Grueling Asia Tour
item.description: The 11-day trip, a signal that Francis does not intend to slow down, requires nearly 45 hours of air travel and meetings in tropical climates.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Riccardo Antimiani/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Pope Francis last week in St. Peter’s Square, Vatican City. His 11-day trip to Southeast Asia signals he has no intention of reducing his outreach to faraway Catholics.

item.title: Helicopter Crash That Killed Iran’s President Was Caused by Bad Weather, Report Says
item.description: Thick fog was a factor in the May crash that killed President Ebrahim Raisi, an armed forces investigation found. His death shook Iran at a strained moment for the country.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral ceremony for President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran in Tehran in May. A reformist candidate was elected to replace him in July.

item.title: The Quiet Collaboration Between Paralympic Athletes and Their Assistants
item.description: For competition partners who share the mutual goal of winning medals, eye contact or a simple touch can be all the communication that’s needed.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerusa Geber dos Santos of Brazil, right, with her guide, Gabriel Garcia, winning a 100-meter heat in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Record Rainfall Spoils Crops in China, Rattling Leaders
item.description: Some vegetables cost more than they have in five years. Top Chinese officials have made a point of showing that they’re doing something about it.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Vegetable prices in China have gone up in recent weeks after crops were damaged by bouts of heavy rainfall.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Starlink Defies Brazil Court Order to Block X
item.description: The satellite internet service controlled by Elon Musk is refusing to comply with a court order to block his social network, X, regulators said.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja/The New York Times
item.media:description: Starlink, the satellite-internet service controlled by Elon Musk, has 250,000 customers in Brazil.

item.title: What It’s Like in Egypt as Energy Crisis Prompts Early Shop Closures
item.description: It’s so hot in Cairo that people like to go out all night. It might look like a party, but in reality, one shopkeeper said, “everybody is dead on the inside.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Hadeer Mahmoud Ahmed
item.media:description: A darkened market in Cairo at night. To reduce electricity consumption, the government has mandated that commercial shops across the country close by 10 p.m., with some variations and exceptions.

item.title: Cathay Pacific Cancels Flights to Inspect 48 Airbus Aircraft After Engine Issue
item.description: An Airbus A350 jet experienced a problem during a flight that was supposed to travel from Hong Kong to Zurich. The airline has canceled 24 return flights.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Tim Chong/Reuters
item.media:description: A Cathay Pacific Airways Airbus A350 like this one experienced an “engine component failure” and returned to Hong Kong.

item.title: Thousands Gather in Israel for Funeral of Hersh Goldberg-Polin
item.description: It was reminder of the perilous situation facing dozens of remaining hostages still thought to be alive in the war-ravaged Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, one of six hostages whose bodies were retrieved from Gaza, in Jerusalem on Monday

item.title: U.S. Seized an Airplane Owned by Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro
item.description: The Biden administration said the airplane had been illegally exported for Mr. Maduro. U.S. officials accuse him of undermining the results of a presidential election he lost.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A Dassault Falcon 900EX owned and operated by President Nicolás Maduro, among others, at Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport in Florida on Monday.

item.title: UK Suspends Some Arms Sales to Israel
item.description: Britain’s foreign secretary, David Lammy, said there was a “clear risk” some weapons might be used to commit “a serious violation of international humanitarian law.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli jet fighter flying above Sderot, Israel, in October.

item.title: Biden Says Netanyahu Is Not Doing Enough to Free Israeli Hostages
item.description: The president told reporters he would have more to say after a meeting later Monday in the White House Situation Room.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden on the White House lawn on Monday.

item.title: Gao Zhen, Artist Who Critiqued the Cultural Revolution, Is Detained in China
item.description: Mr. Gao is being held on suspicion of slandering China’s heroes and martyrs, an offense punishable by up to three years in prison, his brother said.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gao Zhen, left, and Gao Qiang, with their artwork, “Mao’s Guilt,” in 2009.

item.title: Histadrut, the Labor Union Behind Israel’s Strike, Has Long History of Influence
item.description: The union, which predates Israel’s founding, led a strike last year that helped force Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to suspend a plan to overhaul the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Gili Yaari/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Arnon Bar-David, leader of Israel’s largest labor union, Histadrut, speaking at a protest outside the Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: The Four Mysterious Guardians of the Artist Lee Bul
item.description: This fall the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s facade will feature strange, humanoid sculptures. If they induce a feeling of nausea, that’s what Lee was going for.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: The South Korean artist Lee Bul at a studio in Goyang City, outside Seoul, with her works in progress for the facade of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Anger and grief in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Discovery of 6 Dead Hostages in Gaza Spurs Protest and Division in Israel
item.description: The Israeli military said Sunday that Hamas had killed the hostages before they were discovered by Israeli troops on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Gabby Sobelman, Vivek Shankar and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Almog Sarusi, one of the six hostages whose bodies were found by the Israeli Army, in Raanana, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli Protesters Demand a Deal for the Release of Hostages
item.description: Demonstrations spread across cities around the country after the Israeli military said it had recovered the bodies of six hostages killed in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil, Gabby Sobelman and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of people marching in front of the Israeli military headquarters in Tel Aviv on Sunday night.

item.title: Simon Verity, World-Renowned Stone Carver, Is Dead at 79
item.description: He headed the team that created the statues of biblical figures at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Cathedral Church of St John the Divine (Manhattan, NY)
item.media:credit: G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simon Verity in 1997, working on a statue on the western facade of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Upper Manhattan. He and his team spent parts of nine years carving 31 biblical figures and various scenes in the niches that frame the great brass doors at the church’s Portal of Paradise.

item.title: East Germans Lean Toward Extremes in State Elections
item.description: The Alternative for Germany party was on course to win in Thuringia, according to projections, in what was seen as a worrying sign of the health of German democracy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Wolfgang Rattay/Reuters
item.media:description: An Election Day gathering for the far-right AfD party on Sunday in Erfurt, Germany.

item.title: Helicopter Crash Near Volcano in Russia’s Far East Kills at Least 17
item.description: The helicopter was flying tourists in Russia’s Kamchatka region. No survivors were expected among the 22 people on board, state news agencies said.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Russian Emergencies Ministry, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Russian emergencies ministry showing the crash site of a helicopter in Kamchatka, Russia.

item.title: Three Israeli Police Officers Killed in the West Bank
item.description: The officers were shot and killed in what the Israeli police said was a terrorist attack. The incident followed a rise in Palestinian and Israeli violence, as Israel’s military raids Palestinian cities.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Illean/Associated Press
item.media:description: Israeli security forces and emergency workers at the scene of a shooting attack in the West Bank on Sunday.

item.title: Israeli-American Hersh Goldberg-Polin Among 6 Hostages Killed in Gaza
item.description: One of the hostages, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, was an American citizen.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: The Hostages and Missing Families Forum, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Carmel Gat, Eden Yerushalmi, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, Ori Danino, Almog Sarusi and Alexander Lobanov, in photos released by the Hostages and Missing Families Forum.

item.title: Russians Bomb Kharkiv, Ukraine Says, After Russia Reports Wave of Attacks
item.description: Ukraine said Russia struck the country’s second-largest city with missiles and bombs. Russian state media and local officials earlier reported that Ukraine attacked power plants and refineries with drones.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and David Guttenfelder
item.media:description: A Ukrainian rescue worker comforting a resident after what Ukrainian officials said was a Russian missile strike in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: China and the Philippines Collide Again in the South China Sea
item.description: The United States condemned the episode near Sabina Shoal in the South China Sea and reaffirmed its defense treaty with Manila.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Philippine Coast Guard
item.media:description: A screen grab of a video released by the Philippine Coast Guard that it said showed a Chinese Coast Guard ship colliding with a Philippine vessel near Sabina Shoal on Saturday.

item.title: With Russia on Its Doorstep, a Ukrainian Town Packs Its Bags
item.description: Ukraine gambled that its move into Russia would draw Moscow’s forces away from the town of Pokrovsk. It didn’t happen. And now resigned residents are evacuating daily.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waving goodbye to relatives as they left on an evacuation train in Pokrovsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Dragons and Sharks on a Beach Near You: The Story of the Great Lego Spill
item.description: Nearly five million Lego pieces plunged into the sea in 1997. The pieces are still showing up — on England’s coast, in Ireland, Belgium, France and possibly at the beach near you.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Guy Martin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many come to Perranporth Beach, near Cornwall, looking for Lego bricks that fell off a cargo ship in 1997 and are still washing up. Tracey Williams has been documenting Lego finds from that ship for years.

item.title: Israel’s Military Says Hostages Were Killed by Hamas
item.description: One of the victims, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, was a dual Israeli American citizen.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Gabby Sobelman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: The Hostages Families Forum, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Carmel Gat, Eden Yerushalmi, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, Ori Danino, Almog Sarusi and Alexander Lobanov, in photos released by the Hostages and Missing Families Forum.

item.title: In Race Against Polio, Gaza Begins Vaccination Drive
item.description: Israel and Hamas agreed to pause the war to permit the vaccination of 640,000 children in Gaza, a daunting effort for health workers.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair, Erika Solomon and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Eyad Baba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A health worker administering the polio vaccine to a Palestinian child in the central Gaza Strip on Sunday.

item.title: What to Watch For in East German State Elections on Sunday
item.description: The prospect of a strong performance by the far-right Alternative for Germany party in two state elections is only one of the problems for Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: A campaign poster for the far-right Alternative for Germany party in Straussfurt, a village in the eastern German state of Thuringia.

item.title: The Venezuelan City Devastated By Migration
item.description: About a quarter of the residents of Maracaibo, Venezuela’s second-largest city, have moved away — and more are expected to soon follow.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Marian Carrasquero
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irma Palmar, 52, cares for her seven grandchildren at her home in Maricaibo, Venezuela.

item.title: India’s Doctors Are Overworked and Feeling Unsafe
item.description: Grueling shifts, abuse from the public and subpar security are nothing new to medical workers in India, where a ghastly killing has put a spotlight on their plight.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: R. Satish Babu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Medical workers at a government hospital in Chennai, India, in May.

item.title: Israel Says It Has Recovered More Bodies in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military asked the public not to speculate, but many Israelis assumed the announcement referred to dead hostages. The news amplified calls for a cease-fire and hostage-release deal.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Abir Sultan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Families of Israeli hostages held by Hamas arranged a display of more than 100 hostages’ pictures outside the home of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday.

item.title: Eiffel Tower Will Keep Olympic Rings Permanently, Mayor Says
item.description: “I want the two to remain married,” Mayor Anne Hidalgo of Paris said in a newspaper interview.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists along the Seine across from the Eiffel Tower in Paris in July.

item.title: Hvaldimir the ‘Spy’ Whale Is Found Dead in Norwegian Waters
item.description: The beluga whale, who was first spotted in 2019 wearing what looked like a camera harness, was seen floating in Norwegian waters on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Jorgen Ree Wiig/Norwegian Directorate of Fisheries, via Reuters
item.media:description: Hvaldimir the Beluga whale was found dead on Saturday in Norway.

item.title: Why Brazil Banned X
item.description: To combat disinformation, Brazil gave one judge broad power to police the internet. Now, after he blocked X, some are wondering whether that was a good idea.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Ton Molina/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Alexandre de Moraes, a Brazilian Supreme Court justice, on Thursday in Brasília. Justice Moraes has sweeping powers to police content on Brazil’s internet.

item.title: As Ukraine Mourns a Pilot’s Death, Jet’s Crash Is Still a Mystery
item.description: In a reversal, two senior U.S. military officials say the cause of the F-16’s crash was probably not friendly fire.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Libkos/Getty Images
item.media:description: The son of Lt. Col. Oleksiy Mes, a Ukrainian F-16 pilot, holding a framed photo of his father during Colonel Mes’s funeral on Thursday in Shepetivka, Ukraine.

item.title: Norway’s Princess Martha Louise Weds Self-Proclaimed Shaman Durek Verrett
item.description: The nuptials of Princess Martha Louise and Durek Verrett attracted huge public interest and a streaming deal for a couple trying to reclaim their narrative after years of bad press.
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Cornelius Poppe/NTB, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Princess Martha Louise and Durek Verrett, both waving, aboard the royal yacht arriving in Geiranger, Norway, on Friday.

item.title: As Israel Keeps Fighting in West Bank, Residents in One Battle Zone Reel From the Damage
item.description: In the Nur Shams area near Tulkarm, Israeli bulldozers have chewed up large chunks of the roads, and many homes have been left without running water and internet. One family mourned the death of a relative they said was killed in the raid.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Alaa Badarneh/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Palestinians salvaged items after an Israeli military raid in the Nur Shams area of the West Bank on Friday.

item.title: A Playlist to Remember
item.description: Songs can help demarcate this chapter of your life: It’s a way to mark time, to keep one period of time from bleeding indistinctly into the next.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Will Alberta Replace the Mounties With Its Own Provincial Police Force?
item.description: Danielle Smith, the premier, told party supporters that the government would expand the role of its sheriffs.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Todd Korol/Reuters
item.media:description: Danielle Smith recently said that Alberta would create a new police force through its sheriffs service.

item.title: Gaza, Lebanon, West Bank: Why Is Israel Fighting So Many Wars?
item.description: As well as its conflict with Hamas, Israel is battling along its border with Lebanon, waging a counterinsurgency in the occupied West Bank and exchanging sporadic fire with Iran and its regional proxies.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Jaafar Ashtiyeh/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the city of Tulkarm, in the occupied West Bank, on Thursday. Many Israelis have lost hope of using diplomacy to resolve their conflict with the Palestinians.

item.title: Russia’s Youngest Conscripts Unexpectedly See Combat Against Ukraine’s Invasion
item.description: The long-sacrosanct practice of keeping young Russian army conscripts off the front lines is eroding as the lack of troops in Russia’s Kursk region indicates a manpower shortage.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians removing the body of a Russian soldier found in the rubble of a Russian border post this month.

item.title: Hurling, a Centuries-Old Irish Sport, Turns to New Materials
item.description: For centuries, the sport’s wooden sticks have been made from Ireland’s ash trees. But with a disease destroying forests, the ancient game is turning to different materials.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hurling match in the village of Ballyagran, southern Ireland. To an outsider, the sport can look like a combination of lacrosse, baseball and rugby.

item.title: Something’s Poisoning America’s Land. Farmers Fear ‘Forever’ Chemicals.
item.description: Fertilizer made from city sewage has been spread on millions of acres of farmland for decades. Scientists say it can contain high levels of the toxic substance.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times

item.title: Gaza Polio Crisis: What We Know
item.description: Israel and Hamas have agreed to brief pauses in fighting so that humanitarian workers can begin an inoculation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Hatem Khaled/Reuters
item.media:description: A Palestinian child is examined by a doctor at Nasser Hospital, in Khan Younis, as United Nations officials prepare to launch a polio vaccination campaign on Sunday.

item.title: The Angry East
item.description: As east Germans vote, a region in decline is searching for answers on the political extremes.
item.dc:creator: Ingmar Nolting and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: This region used to power the former East Germany with its coal mines.

item.title: The Debate in Singapore About the New Statue of Raffles
item.description: The tribute to Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles, who is considered the founder of Singapore, has raised questions about how the wealthy city-state perceives its history.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new statue of Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles in Fort Canning Park in Singapore in July.

item.title: What to Know About Putin’s Planned Visit to Mongolia Amid ICC Arrest Warrant
item.description: The Russian president will travel to Mongolia, a member of the International Criminal Court, which issued a warrant for his arrest in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Gavriil Grigorov/Sputnik
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state news media of President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with President Ukhnaagiin Khurelsukh of Mongolia in July in Astana, Kazakhstan.

item.title: Brazil Blocks X After Musk Ignores Court Orders
item.description: The social network began to go dark in the nation of 200 million, the result of an escalating fight between Elon Musk and a Brazilian judge over what can be said online.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
item.media:description: X will be banned in Brazil after Elon Musk refused to comply with a Brazilian judge’s orders to suspend certain accounts.

item.title: Gaza Faces Polio Threat After 11 Months of War
item.description: Starting Sunday, the Israeli military and Hamas will observe brief, staggered pauses in fighting to allow 640,000 Gazan children to be vaccinated, U.N. officials said.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Ramadan Abed/Reuters
item.media:description: Nivine Abu Al-Jidyan tending to her son Abdul Rahman Abu Al-Jidyan in their tent in Deir al Balah, in the central Gaza Strip, on Wednesday. Abdul Rahman was the first person to contract polio in Gaza in 25 years.

item.title: Maduro Appears to Send Two Foreign Members of Ukraine’s Military to Face Trial in Russia
item.description: Two Colombian soldiers who had fought for Ukraine are now under arrest in Moscow. They wound up there after stopping over in Venezuela, which apparently extradited them.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Simón Posada and Oleg Matsnev
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreign fighters with the Carpathian Sich Battalion near Lyman, Ukraine, in 2022. The detained Colombian fighters both served with the battalion in Ukraine.

item.title: Why Oil Prices Remain Subdued
item.description: Despite war in the Middle East and political turmoil in Libya, investors are focusing on what look like ample global supplies.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Houston oil refinery. The United States is increasing its output along with Brazil, Canada and Guyana.

item.title: Zelensky Dismisses the Head of the Air Force Days After F-16 Crash
item.description: The Ukrainian president gave no reason, but there are indications that friendly fire may have brought down the jet, a Western official said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Libkos/Getty Images
item.media:description: The funeral for Oleksiy Mes, an F-16 pilot who died in Ukraine this week.
